questions.text: Which IEC 62304 software safety class requires software detailed design documentation?

options.explanation: Class A has the least rigorous requirements and does not require detailed design.
Class B requires architectural design but not detailed design.
Per Section 5.2, software detailed design is only required for Class C software.
Detailed design is required only for Class C, not all classes.

questions.text: What is the minimum code review requirement per this SOP?

options.explanation: Code review is required for Class B and C software.

options.text: All changes reviewed by at least one independent reviewer
options.explanation: Per Section 5.6, all changes must be reviewed by at least one independent reviewer.

options.text: Only critical bug fixes need review
options.explanation: All changes require review, not just critical fixes.

options.text: Review by the same developer who wrote the code
options.explanation: The reviewer must be independent of the author.

questions.text: Software with safety class A does not require software system testing.
questions.explanation: Per Section 5.2, software system testing is required for all safety classes (A, B, and C).

questions.text: What must be done before releasing medical device software?

options.explanation: Passing tests is necessary but not sufficient; several other criteria must be met.

options.text: All V&V complete, known anomalies documented with risk assessment, release notes prepared, signatures obtained, artifacts archived
options.explanation: Per Section 5.9, all five release criteria must be satisfied before release.
Release requires verification completion, documentation, and signatures â€” not just one approval.
Customer approval is not a release prerequisite.

questions.text: What is SOUP and how must it be managed?

options.text: Software developed internally; no special management needed
options.explanation: SOUP is pre-existing software not developed under a known process, and it requires specific management.

options.text: Pre-existing software requiring identification, risk assessment, and monitoring
options.explanation: Per Section 5.10, SOUP must be identified, have requirements defined, risk assessed, and monitored for vulnerabilities and updates.

options.text: Open-source software that can be used without restrictions
options.explanation: SOUP requires formal risk assessment and monitoring regardless of its license type.

options.text: Software under test that has not been verified
options.explanation: SOUP refers to pre-existing software of unknown provenance, not software under test.
